key_points: President Joe Biden issued a national security memorandum to improve cybersecurity in critical infrastructure.
The memorandum seeks to encourage voluntary adoption of improved cybersecurity standards by infrastructure owners and operators.
It addresses the 'patchwork' of sector-specific statutes and aims for more coherent cybersecurity measures.
Focuses specifically on industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technologies (OT), crucial for the functionality of infrastructure.
The initiative responds to the increasing threat and potential consequences of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure.
Around 80% to 90% of critical infrastructure is privately owned, complicating government efforts to protect it.
The memorandum emphasizes a 'whole-of-nation' approach and seeks to improve cyber information sharing between the private sector and government.
It follows a slew of high-profile cyberattacks and is part of the administration's broader strategy to improve national cybersecurity.
The memorandum is one of various measures by the administration, including past executive orders and initiatives targeting ransomware and infrastructure security.
The administration is exploring both voluntary and mandatory options for improving cybersecurity in the face of urgent threats.
